title: Finding Housing in Switzerland: Complete Guide
subtitle: Homegate, ImmoScout24 and secrets to successful renting
bodyMarkdown:
# Finding Housing in Switzerland

The rental market in Switzerland is highly competitive. Up to 50-200 people may apply for one apartment. Prepare in advance!

## Where to Search

### Top Platforms
1. **homegate.ch** â€” largest portal (80% of listings)
2. **immoscout24.ch** â€” popular alternative
3. **tutti.ch** â€” private listings
4. **wgzimmer.ch** â€” rooms and shared housing
5. **Facebook groups** â€” quick listings

## Rental Costs

### Zurich
- 1 room: 1200-1800 CHF
- 2 rooms: 1600-2500 CHF
- 3 rooms: 2200-3500 CHF

### Bern
- 1 room: 900-1400 CHF
- 2 rooms: 1200-1900 CHF

## Application Documents

- [ ] Betreibungsregisterauszug (debt certificate)
- [ ] Passport and Ausweis copy
- [ ] Income proof (last 3 pay slips)
- [ ] Employment contract
- [ ] Motivation letter

## Tips & Tricks

> **Insider tip**: Apply within 1-2 hours of listing publication!

> **Advice**: Write a personal letter to the landlord â€” this sets you apart from others.

## Nebenkosten

Additional costs (150-300 CHF/month):
- Heating
- Water
- Stairway cleaning
- Garbage disposal

title: Mietkaution: Everything About Rental Deposit
subtitle: How much to pay, how to get it back, and common mistakes
bodyMarkdown:
# Mietkaution â€” Rental Deposit

When renting in Switzerland, you must pay a deposit (Kaution). This is mandatory practice.

## Deposit Amount

- **Standard**: 2-3 months' rent (excluding Nebenkosten)
- **Example**: Rent 1500 CHF â†’ Deposit 3000-4500 CHF

## How to Pay

### Correct Method
1. Open a **Mietkaution-Konto** at a bank
2. Deposit the amount into a blocked account
3. Account is in your name, but you cannot withdraw
4. Interest accrues to you

### NEVER Do This
- âŒ Don't pay cash to landlord
- âŒ Don't transfer to owner's personal account

## Getting Your Deposit Back

### After Moving Out
1. Conduct WohnungsÃ¼bergabe (apartment handover)
2. Sign the protocol
3. Landlord releases deposit within 1-12 months

### If There's Damage
- Deducted from deposit
- Remainder is returned

## Alternatives

### Kautionsversicherung (deposit insurance)
- Pay 4-5% annually instead of full amount
- Companies: SwissCaution, Firstcaution
- Example: instead of 4500 CHF, pay 180-225 CHF/year

> **Insider tip**: Some SozialÃ¤mter help with deposits. Ask!

## Key Terms

- **Mietkaution** â€” deposit
- **Sperrkonto** â€” blocked account
- **WohnungsÃ¼bergabe** â€” apartment handover
- **Protokoll** â€” handover protocol

title: Tenant Rights in Switzerland
subtitle: What you can and cannot do, and how to protect yourself
bodyMarkdown:
# Tenant Rights in Switzerland

Swiss law provides strong tenant protection. Know your rights!

## Basic Rights

### Eviction Protection
- Landlord cannot evict without reason
- 3 months notice required (usually)
- Can appeal to SchlichtungsbehÃ¶rde

### Repairs and Maintenance
- Major repairs â€” landlord's responsibility
- Minor repairs (up to 150 CHF) â€” tenant
- Report issues in writing

### Rent Reduction
- For apartment defects (MÃ¤ngel)
- When Referenzzinssatz (base rate) drops
- Through Mieterverband

## Tenant Obligations

- [ ] Pay rent on time
- [ ] Follow Hausordnung
- [ ] Report damage
- [ ] No renovations without permission

## Hausordnung (House Rules)

### Typical Rules
- Quiet after 10 PM
- Laundry room by schedule
- Garbage sorting
- Hallway cleanliness

## Where to Get Help

### Mieterverband (Tenants' Association)
- Rental consultations
- Help with letters
- Court representation
- Membership: 70-120 CHF/year

### SchlichtungsbehÃ¶rde
- Free mediation
- Mandatory before court

> **Insider tip**: Join Mieterverband immediately â€” they'll save you in conflict situations!
